articles.description: When the Spanish flu ravaged, nurses had no protective equipment and cared for sick patients in the city’s slums. How the deadly outbreak shaped today’s fight.
articles.content:
Melbourne was the Australian epicentre of the Spanish flu outbreak in 1919, and a small band of district nurses were forced to change their methods to help our city's poorest people survive the pandemic.
Some of those changes stuck and remain today as Victor… [+7515 chars]

articles.title: At Least 90,000 Health Workers Worldwide Have Tested Positive To Covid-19 - 10 daily
articles.description: At least 90,000 health-care workers worldwide are believed to have been infected with Covid-19, and possibly twice that, amid reports of continuing shortages of protective equipment.
articles.content:
At least 90,000 health-care workers worldwide are believed to have been infected with Covid-19, and possibly twice that, amid reports of continuing shortages of protective equipment.
The International Council of Nurses (ICN) said the disease has killed more … [+1505 chars]

articles.title: Three words behind Australia's success - Ballina Shire Advocate
articles.description: The four countries worst hit by COVID-19 share a classification by the World Health Organisation that “we don’t want”, an Australian epidemiologist says.
articles.content:
When COVID-19 reached Australian shores, the country acted quickly.
Pubs and gyms closed on Monday, March 23. Seven deaths had been recorded in Australia at the time compared to almost 200 deaths in the UK when they decided to shutter their cafes and restaur… [+8034 chars]
